Dear Ms. Shillings:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/12/24. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan
is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action
plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer, at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(4) Training opportunities for direct care staff shall
include, but are not limited to, all of the following: (h) First
aid.
Three of forty staff files did not have documentation of first-aid/CPR training.
2

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The agency was provided information on utilizing the Child Welfare Licensing
Module (CWLM) system to enter Corrective Action Plan (CAP) information.
• Strategies were discussed to increase activities and programming for youth, in an
effort to decrease truancy of youth.
• Residential Collaboration and Technical Assistance Unit (RCTAU) analyst
provided additional support on-site during this review period.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Coordination with the Building Bridges Initiative began in June 2024.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were three incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing period:
Special Investigation 2023C0000590SI with CAP approval date of 9/22/23 was a result
of a violation for rule 158 (1a,ii) Intervention Standards and Prohibitions, and rule 112 (2
and 4a,b) staff qualifications. It was determined a supervisor verbally instigated a youth,
as well as grabbed, hit and forcibly moved youth on the floor. The supervisor
demonstrated an inability to perform duties. As a result, supervisor was terminated from
employment, and behavior management refresher training was completed with all staff.
The agency completed CAP items and monitoring ended in March 2024.
Special Investigation 2024C0001082SI with CAP approval date of 4/11/24 was a result
of a violation of rule 158(1a,ii) intervention standards and prohibitions, 127(1) staff to
resident ratio, and 109(1c) program statement. It was determined the facility was not
functioning in the approved staff to youth ratio, staff used a chokehold on a youth, and
incident reports were not completed as required. As a result, the agency terminated
staff, increased training, decreased available shelter beds, increased supervision of
staff, and provided training regarding incident report writing. The agency completed
CAP items and monitoring ended in August 2024.
Special Investigation 2024C0001139SI with CAP approval date of 4/9/24 was a result of
a violation of rule 158(1a,ii) intervention standards and prohibitions, rule 131 child
protection law, rule 162(11) seclusion, 163(5) health status assessment notification
debriefing and reporting. It was determined supervisor pushed a youth and held the
youth by wrapping their arm around the youth’s neck. Supervisor also held the youth’s
bedroom door shut in order to prevent exit. Supervisor restrained youth multiple times
without completing incident reports. In addition, staff failed to report the alleged abuse
that was witnessed. As a result, the agency terminated the supervisor, behavior
management became a weekly discussion topic at staff meetings, staff were retrained
3

on mandated reporting, restraint training as reviewed, prohibition of seclusion was
reviewed, and incident report writing was reviewed with staff. The agency has taken
steps to implement this CAP. However, CAP compliance monitoring is ongoing at this
time.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted nine acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility renewal inspection was completed on 7/28/23 and the CAP was
approved on 8/11/23. The facility was cited for seven violations. Improvement was
found in all areas of non-compliance during this review period as there were no
repeat violations cited.
Special Investigation 20240000882SI with CAP approval date of 12/15/23 was a
result of a violation of rule 159(2g) restraint, reduction, prevention; prohibited
restraints. The agency completed CAP items and there have been no repeat
violations since that time.
Special Investigation 2024C0001113SI with CAP approval date of 4/1/24 was a
result of a violation of rule 142(1e and 1f) health services. The agency completed
CAP items and there have been no repeat violations since that time.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001301 with CAP approval date of 8/19/24 was a
result of a violation of rule 159(2e) restraints. The agency has taken steps to
implement this CAP. However, CAP compliance monitoring is ongoing at this time.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001424 with CAP approval date of 8/29/24 was the
result of a repeat violation of rule 158(1a) intervention standards and prohibitions.
The agency has taken steps to implement this CAP. However, CAP compliance
monitoring is ongoing at this time.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001472 with CAP approval date of 8/19/24 was a
result of a violation of rule 157(1) behavior management. The agency has taken
steps to implement this CAP. However, CAP compliance monitoring is ongoing at
this time.
Financial Overview
The agency’s annual financial audit and budget were reviewed. No concerns were
noted.
During the interim review process, two special evaluations (2024SIC0001631 and
2024SIC0001632) were opened regarding financial concerns about Wolverine
Human Services, the parent company to Wolverine Center and two other licensed
programs. A review of financial documents and interviews with youth and staff
4

were completed. It was determined the agency was in compliance, as all youth
needs continue to be met.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment dated 7/22/24 was reviewed and discussed
on-site. The Chief Administrator (CA) reported successful implementation of the
2023 renewal CAP. The CA identified ongoing compliance in all areas cited
previously. The CA did not identify any barriers or systemic factors that impacted
compliance. As a result of the CAP, the agency implemented several techniques to
maintain compliance. These actions appear to be successful as there were no
repeat violations found during the interim review.
The CA reported 34 unplanned discharges during this report period. The
discharges were due to truancy, hospitalization, and escalation to a secured
setting. The CA reported that truancy continues to be a problem, due to the facility
not being a secured setting. The facility has attempted to prevent truancy by
building relationships with youth, incentives, increased activities, and more frequent
outings.
The CA identified one current challenge being the no eject/reject contract with
MDHHS. Due to this contract, the facility must accept placement of all youth,
including those with significant behavioral issues. The facility reported several
incidents of youth attacking and injuring staff. Some steps taken to address this
concern were ongoing staff training in de-escalation, overlapping shifts, reviews of
incident reports, increased frequency of staff meetings, purchasing new radios for
staff to communicate when assistance was needed, and a decrease in beds related
to that contract in order to right size the program. The agency continues to voice
opposition to the no eject/reject clause of the contract and will continue meeting
with MDHHS regarding this concern.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three staff were interviewed on-site. One staff had been with the facility for over a
year and reported being satisfied with their role at the agency. Staff admitted the
job can be challenging at times. However, they had no suggestions for
improvement. The other two staff joined the program within the past 90-days and
stated their training was helpful and communication with supervisor and
administration was informative and supportive. One staff stated they were unsure of
what areas the agency could improve upon. The other staff stated they wished
youth had more opportunities to be active in the community, especially during the
summer months when school is out.
All three staff reported receiving sufficient training and support from supervision
and administration.
Four youth were interviewed on-site. All youth reported they felt safe, received
enough food, and did not have any concerns about the staff. Youth stated they
5

sometimes felt unsafe because of their peers actions, but not because of staff
actions. Youth indicate they did not like being in residential treatment but did not
have anything specific they disliked about Wolverine Center. When asked about
anything they would change, youth stated they would like to have more personal
belongings, more outings, and different food options.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same building as the 2023 review. While
the building is old and continues to need updating, it was observed to be clean and
safe. The bedrooms were found to be a comfortable temperature and had
appropriate bedding. The kitchen was clean, had a sufficient amount of food, and
weekly meal menus with a variety of options. Staff and visitation areas were clean
and appropriate for use. No concerns were identified.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
